cmCourseInfo.description: Structure of the human body and its relationship to function. Basic Human Histology, Gross Anatomy, and Neuroanatomy. Some content is delivered using online modules.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Anatomy and Histology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

There are eight hours of e-modules/lectures each week. 

In addition, each week there will be two, one-hour tutorials. Students must enrol in a tutorial to attend synchronously.

Delivery Instructions

Course content will be taught using a mixture of e-modules and either synchronous or asynchronous lectures. Synchronous lectures will be recorded for asynchronous attendance. When content is delivered asynchronously, either via an e-module or recorded lecture, students will be given the opportunity to ask questions of the Course Director during a corresponding synchronous session during the scheduled class time. Weekly synchronous tutorials will emphasize practical anatomy and will not be recorded; students must attend their online tutorial at their scheduled time. Students must have access to a stable internet connection.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project in Histology, Cellular or Molecular Biology, Developmental Biology, Neuroanatomy or Gross Anatomy. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Project in Anatomy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of a professor to supervise the project

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit a completed ANA498Y1Y ballot to anatomy@utoronto.ca by Monday, April 26th 2021, before being approved and enrolled. Ballots are available on the course website: https://surgery.utoronto.ca/division-anatomy-arts-science-undergraduate-courses

Delivery Instructions

Course workload is self-paced, ensuring deadlines are met. Weekly meetings may be scheduled, this is up to each Supervisor's discretion and needs for each individual's project. Students need access to a stable internet connection, and Quercus. Students may need access to software required for their particular research project.

cmCourseInfo.description: Society and culture from various anthropological perspectives: socio-cultural, evolutionary, archaeological, and linguistic.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Anthropology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given online, synchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week (Professor and 2 TAs) to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

cmCourseInfo.description: A course focused on recent anthropological scholarship that seeks to understand and explain the transformation of contemporary societies and cultures. Topics may include some of the following: new patterns of global inequality, war and neo-colonialism, health and globalization, social justice and indigeneity, religious fundamentalism, gender inequalities, biotechnologies and society etc.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

For ANT204H, there will be a combination of synchronous and asynchronous lectures, with selected pre-recorded lectures which will be outlined on the syllabus. The lectures will be recorded and uploaded after each lecture to support students who would need a second listen. There will also be opportunities for students to participate in synchronous lectures through activities/breakout rooms when prompted by the Instructure.  Tutorials will be synchronous.

courses.name: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

cmCourseInfo.description: Society, culture, kinship, exchange, community, identity, politics, belief: these and other core concepts are explored in this course, which lays the foundation for advanced courses in social and cultural anthropology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to applied evolutionary medical anthropology. It explores evidence for the evolution of human vulnerability to disease across the life cycle (conception to death) and implications for health of contemporary populations in behavioral ecological, cross-cultural, health and healing systems, historical trauma, inter-sectionality, and climate change, lenses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. They will be posted each week prior to synchronous lectures. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous, at their scheduled times (see Calendar). Students are expected to view recorded lectures prior to meeting virtually with their Teaching Assistant for online synchronous tutorials. For tutorials, it would be helpful for students to have access to a microphone and/or camera. Access to a microphone and/or camera would also be helpful if students want to meet with the instructor virtually during their synchronous office hours (see Syllabus).

cmCourseInfo.description: Social anthropological perspectives on variations in gender roles and systems. Examines, through comparison of ethnography, the relationship of gender to social organization, economic and political processes, belief systems and social change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Anthropology of Gender

cmCourseInfo.description: Social anthropological perspective on the nature and meaning of food production, culinary cultures, industrial food, food as metaphor, and famine and hunger.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Food

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be an online synchronous course, with lecture recordings available for asynchronous viewing.

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: Health, Power and Politics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deepens students’ understandings of health and illness as social, cultural, political and historical phenomena. Drawing on theories and approaches from social-cultural anthropology, students will develop skills in critical analysis of experiences and meanings of healing and illness in particular contexts, with a focus on anthropological critique of dominant health policies, discourses, technologies and practices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: Health, Power and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or permission of the instructor. (Note: ANT208H1 is not accepted preparation for this course.)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered via asynchronous videos posted online.

One two-hour live class session per week will include small group and whole-class discussion of readings and course material to support student comprehension, and updates and feedback on assignments from the teaching team.  It is recommended but not required that students complete readings and watch lecture videos prior to these live sessions. Participation in the live sessions is strongly recommended but optional. It will require a microphone and ideally a camera. Video recordings of whole class discussion will be posted for those unable to participate in live sessions.

cmCourseInfo.description: Our place in the Universe. Phenomena we see in the sky. What we know about the Sun, the planets and comets, and the formation of the solar system – and how we know it. What makes planets suitable for life. Finding out about the nearest stars and their planets. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Sun and Its Neighbours
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: AST121H1, AST221H1. All lectures will be recorded for students wishing to take the course asynchronously. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate via Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: What we know about the properties and life cycles of stars, of galaxies, and of the Universe itself – and how we know it. How astronomers develop methods for understanding phenomena that span such vast ranges in distance and time. This course is intended for students with no science or engineering background.
cmCourseInfo.title: Stars and Galaxies

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. CHM110H5 & CHM120H5 (UTM) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMA10H3 & CHMA11H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM135H1 ONLY. CHMB41H3/CHMB42H3 (UTSC) are equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY.  CHM242H5 (UTM) is equivalent to CHM136H1 ONLY. Students with a SDF in CHM135H1/CHM136H1 are not permitted to enrol in BCH210H1 until a final passing grade (50%) appears on the transcript.

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

BCH210H1F is an Online - Synchronous course administered through Quercus.

Content lectures will be delivered asynchronously as pre-recorded online videos available on a weekly basis with accompanying questions to be answered in Quercus. Weekly quizzes based on the lecture content will be available for completion each week on Fridays, also through Quercus.  Synchronous overview lectures will be delivered each week on Quercus on Mondays from 10-11 am, but will be recorded for viewing at a later date/time. Students will have the opportunity to participate in synchronous and recorded, online tutorials once per week (Thursdays 3-5 pm or Fridays 9-11 am), which involve working through problems and Q&A with a tutorial TA using Blackboard Collaborate. 5% of the assessments will be for tutorial participation. Note – tutorial attendance is the only mandatory, synchronous portion requiring attendance for this course.

All material for lectures, tutorials and assignments will be available as downloadable pdf files through Quercus.

In addition to a high-speed internet connection for the viewing of lectures, participation of tutorials, and completion of online quizzes, students will also require internet search capability including the access to journal articles through the University of Toronto library network.  Assignments can be done offline but will require the use of word processing software and the submission of digital pdf files.  Students will also learn to use protein visualization tools either through the internet or by downloading free programs to their personal computers.

65% of the term work will be “take-home” assessments submitted at various points throughout the course. Online questions and quizzes completed on a weekly basis throughout the term will be worth 30%, and the remaining 5% will be for synchronous online participation during tutorials.

Blackboard Collaborate will also be used for online office hours (Thursdays and Fridays from 1-2 pm) for assistance with the content and questions regarding the assignments.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A final grade of 75% or higher in each of BCH340H1; BCH377H1; BCH378H1; and approval of the course coordinator.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To enrol in this course, please send an email, with your student #, to jennifer.haughton@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

In-person labs will be held if possible following institutional and public health guidance for physical distancing.

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles and concepts of evolution and ecology related to origins of adaptation and biodiversity. Mechanisms and processes driving biological diversification illustrated from various perspectives using empirical and theoretical approaches. Topics include: genetic diversity, natural selection, speciation, physiological, population, and community ecology, maintenance of species diversity, conservation, species extinction, global environmental change, and invasion biology. A lab coat is required and the cost is approximately $16 if students wish to purchase it through the Department. (Lab Materials Fee: $25)
cmCourseInfo.title: Adaptation and Biodiversity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Grade 12 Biology or equivalent. Students without high school Biology must consult the BIO120 Office (bio120@utoronto.ca)

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. 
Lectures will be given as two 2 hr online videos a week synchronously. 
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online tutorials with the lecturer each week. 
Labs will run synchronously online Tuesdays (P0101) or Thursdays (P0201) from 1-4 pm. 
Students need to be online during their scheduled lab time. 
For more information, please contact bio120@utoronto.ca
Students will need: regular access to a computer (note that smartphones are not guaranteed to work for all aspects of the course, and a laptop or desktop computer is recommended); an Internet connection and web browser that allows use of Quercus and Bb Collaborate ; Word processing software (if you do not already have this, Office 365 ProPlus can be accessed through U of T).

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the goals of modern biology is to understand how the basic building blocks of life give rise to biological form and function. This course provides students with a common lexicon to understand the key principles and concepts in molecular and cell biology, with a focus on how the building blocks of life lead to functioning cells. (Lab Materials Fee: $10). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular and Cell Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry) or permission of department. Please contact bio130@utoronto.ca for more information.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Work associated with labs will begin the second week of class. All labs are on Mondays from 1-4 pm and students need to be available online during this time. You can find out your lab group (e.g., P0101A) by logging into Quercus and looking under the Groups section. The lab manual and all course information will be available on the course website on Quercus. For more information, please contact bio130@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Delivery of lectures and practicals will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. The course instructor will provide details on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: The genome is the "book of life," providing instructions to construct an organism. This course introduces genome biology and explores how the building blocks of life are networked into functioning organisms. We will investigate how cells perceive internal and external cues, how gene expression is shaped by this perception, and how these events give rise to tissues, organs, and whole organisms. (Lab Materials Fee: $15). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: From Genes to Organisms

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Laboratory enrolment can be done on ACORN until the evening of Monday May 3rd. Late lab enrolment or lab changes must be done by emailing the BIO230H1 Office at bio230@utoronto.ca. You can find out your lab group (e.g., P0101A) by logging into Quercus and looking under the Groups section. The lab manual and all course information will be available on Quercus.

Delivery Instructions

Delivery of lectures and practicals will occur through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online components. The course instructor will provide details on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Animal physiology is a biological sub-discipline that aims to understand, in physical and chemical terms, how animals work. This course uses examples from throughout the animal kingdom, in a comparative approach, to introduce and study homeostasis and the endocrine system. Accompanying laboratories reinforce concepts introduced in lectures and provide opportunities for students to experience firsthand the role that experimentation, data collection, interpretation of data, and communication of data plays in the nature of the scientific process. (Lab Materials Fee: $10). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Animal Physiology I

courses.name: Culture and the Media in Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the encounter between culture and mass communication in Canadian society. The course considers the role of major cultural institutions such as the CBC, the NFB, and their granting bodies. The emergence of new media and its relationship to mass media is also addressed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Culture and the Media in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be live-streamed and synchronous to enable real-time contact with the professor, the TA and classmates. Students are encouraged to participate online both verbally and using the chat function. The course requirements are two essays and a final assignment/exam. Students who have difficulties due to time zone differences may apply for recordings of the classes.  The professor and TA will be available through office hours or by appointment. Students need the ability to view PDFs or slides. The course will be conducted on Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary course that interrogates the constitution of blackness in Canada. Students will study race and ethnic relations, alongside other identity formations such as class, gender and sexuality. Topics to be addressed include media, education, law, immigration and mobility, urbanism, work, political representation and the arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Black Canadian Studies

notes.name: Course Note

It is recommended that students have access to a microphone and camera to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will introduce students to quantitative research tools developed through the Digital Humanities. Students will learn to use online text analytics tools in order to understand how quantitative methods can support critical academic research of the study of Canada. Quantitative digital analysis will be applied to a wide range of Canadian digital academic archives and community hubs.

notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Most classes will be given asynchronously 3 times x 2 hr. online videos/week, and some will be delivered synchronously through online webinars. Students may attend online “office hours” to ask questions and clarifications about class content: the days/times of these hours are to be determined. 


Tutorial content will be delivered asynchronously once per week, and online webinars will be offered for discussions, questions and clarifications of the tutorial content (twice x 1 hr./week). 
 

Weekly virtual practical exercises will be run synchronously during regularly-scheduled laboratory hours.
Students require access to Microsoft Office (PowerPoint, Excel, and Word) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate. 


The expectation is that students connect to all course activities using a desktop/laptop computer through a web browser using a stable internet connection (not a cellphone).

courses.name: Mizrahim in Israel: History, Politics, and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: What is the significance of the designation “Mizrahi” in Israel today? Does it refer to people who share a common geographical and ethnic origin or does it indicate a shared worldview that draws upon Middle Eastern Arabic culture? What are its relations with other terms, such as “Sephardi,” “Oriental,” or “Levantine”? What kind of political membership does it entail? Does it possess a certain cultural, religious, or political vocabulary? And, ultimately, does the diasporic concept of “Mizrahiyut” (mizrahiness) undermine national homogeneity or rather facilitate and enable its enforcement?
cmCourseInfo.title: Mizrahim in Israel: History, Politics, and Culture
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CJS390H1 (Special Topics in Jewish Studies: Mizrahim in Israel: History, Politics, and Culture), offered in Summer 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: The main principles and themes of Canadian criminal law; legal definitions of crime, requirements of a criminal act (actus reus), criminal intention (mens rea), causation and defences. The origins, goals and functioning of criminal law, and limits on the power of the state to criminalize behaviour.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the intersections between social inequality and the criminal justice system in Canada and internationally. The course explores how factors such as race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation and religion influence perceptions of and experiences with crime and criminal justice.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to social science research methods used by criminologists and to the statistical analysis of criminological data. Specific technical issues related to sampling, measurement, and data analysis are taught in the context of examining ways of answering research questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: The meaning, purposes and sources of interpersonal violence, including an examination of debates over defining and documenting violence, and a review of the research on the relationships between illegitimate, interpersonal violence and state-approved or state-initiated violence. Cultural, social and individual correlates of interpersonal violence; the violence of the law; and how violence is justified and denied.

cmCourseInfo.description: Stem cells provide the basis for cellular diversity in multicellular organisms and have enormous therapeutic potential in regenerative medicine. The course will introduce students to the differences and similarities between stem cells from different organisms, their roles throughout development and therapeutic potential.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how the central and peripheral nervous system controls breathing in mammals. Topics include how the brain generates rhythmic breathing movements, how sleep impacts breathing control and how abnormal breathing contributes to disorders such as sleep apnea.

Please note that we do not manually add non-registered students (including students on the waiting list) to any course platforms (including but not limited to Quercus, Bb Collaborate (Ultra) and any guest access). The course instructor will provide details.

courses.name: Research Abroad in Cell & Systems Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: An independent research project conducted in molecular biology, cell biology, developmental biology, neurobiology, physiology or systems biology. Whole organism, cell culture, in vitro or in silico studies are acceptable. The laboratory research is conducted by the student and supervised by a faculty member at an approved partner university. An information session is held each fall, and an application and interview process is required. The research is typically conducted from May to August. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Abroad in Cell & Systems Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum grade of 73% in BIO230H1/BIO255H1/BIO271H1 and permission of the CSB397Y0 coordinator

courses.name: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

cmCourseInfo.description: An original research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be mutually agreed upon by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. In the Fall or Winter sessions, a commitment of 8-10 hours per week is expected for research and related course activities. If spread over both the Fall and Winter sessions, a commitment of 4-5 hours per week is expected. In the Summer Session, the number of hours doubles per week (e.g., 16-20 for F or S, or 8-10 for Y) as the length of the term is halved compared to the Fall or Winter term. Many students spend more than this amount of time as they become immersed in their project. This course is normally open only to fourth year students with adequate background in Cell and Systems Biology. Course requirements include a final report, and either an oral presentation (Summer and Fall sessions) or a poster presentation (Winter session). Two workshops on scientific research are scheduled and highly recommended. Details for enrollment are available at the Undergraduate course section of the CSB website, http://csb.utoronto.ca. Maximum of 2.0 FCEs allowed among CSB497H1, CSB498Y1 and CSB499Y1. (Lab Materials Fee: $25). Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Cell and Systems Biology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit a completed CSB497/498/499 contract to the CSB Undergraduate Office at janet.mannone@utoronto.ca by Friday, 30 April 2021, before being enrolled. Contracts are available on our website at https://csb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate-studies/forms/. For more information please contact janet.mannone@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project.  The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student.  Students are responsible for contacting possible supervisors.  The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components).  In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Programming in a language such as Python. Elementary data types, lists, maps. Program structure: control flow, functions, classes, objects, methods. Algorithms and problem solving. Searching, sorting, and complexity. Unit testing. No prior programming experience required.

NOTE: You may not take this course concurrently with CSC120H1/CSC148H1, but you may take CSC148H1 after CSC108H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Computer Programming

cmCourseInfo.description: Abstract data types and data structures for implementing them. Linked data structures. Encapsulation and information-hiding. Object-oriented programming. Specifications. Analyzing the efficiency of programs. Recursion. This course assumes programming experience as provided by CSC108H1. Students who already have this background may consult the Computer Science Undergraduate Office for advice about skipping CSC108H1. Practical (P) sections consist of supervised work in the computing laboratory. These sections are offered when facilities are available, and attendance is required. NOTE: Students may go to their college to drop down from CSC148H1 to CSC108H1. See above for the drop down deadline.

courses.name: Mathematical Expression and Reasoning for Computer Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to abstraction and rigour. Informal introduction to logical notation and reasoning. Understanding, using and developing precise expressions of mathematical ideas, including definitions and theorems. Structuring proofs to improve presentation and comprehension. General problem-solving techniques. Running time analysis of iterative programs. Formal definition of Big-Oh. Diagonalization, the Halting Problem, and some reductions. Unified approaches to programming and theoretical problems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mathematical Expression and Reasoning for Computer Science

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to software design and development concepts, methods, and tools using a statically-typed object-oriented programming language such as Java. Topics from: version control, unit testing, refactoring, object-oriented design and development, design patterns, advanced IDE usage, regular expressions, and reflection. Representation of floating-point numbers and introduction to numerical computation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Software Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1  (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC148H1 before completing CSC207H1.)

cmCourseInfo.description: Software techniques in a Unix-style environment, using scripting languages and a machine-oriented programming language (typically C). What goes on in the operating system when programs are executed. Core topics: creating and using software tools, pipes and filters, file processing, shell programming, processes, system calls, signals, basic network programming.

courses.name: Introduction to the Theory of Computation

cmCourseInfo.description: The application of logic and proof techniques to Computer Science. Mathematical induction; correctness proofs for iterative and recursive algorithms; recurrence equations and their solutions; introduction to automata and formal languages. This course assumes university-level experience with proof techniques and algorithmic complexity as provided by CSC165H1. Very strong students who already have this experience (e.g. successful completion of MAT157Y1) may consult the undergraduate office about proceeding directly into CSC236H1 or CSC240H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Theory of Computation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC148H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1, 60% or higher in CSC165H1/ 60% or higher in CSC111H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grade in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the minimum grade for program admission in Computer Science. If you take this course when your grade in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 is lower than the requirement for program admission, you will be unable to enrol in a Computer Science program. If you hope to enrol in a Computer Science program in future, please ensure that you satisfy the program admission grade requirements in CSC165H1/CSC240H1 before completing CSC236H1. Students will not be permitted to retake CSC165H1 after completing CSC236H1.)

cmCourseInfo.description: Computer structures, machine languages, instruction execution, addressing techniques, and digital representation of data. Computer system organization, memory storage devices, and microprogramming. Block diagram circuit realizations of memory, control and arithmetic functions. There are a number of laboratory periods in which students conduct experiments with digital logic circuits.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC148H1, 60% or higher in CSC111H1/CSC165H1/CSC240H1 (Please note: The minimum prerequisite grades in CSC148H1 and CSC165H1/CSC240H1 are lower than the minimum grades for program admission in Computer Science. cmCourseInfo.description: Algorithm analysis: worst-case, average-case, and amortized complexity. Expected worst-case complexity, randomized quicksort and selection. Standard abstract data types, such as graphs, dictionaries, priority queues, and disjoint sets. A variety of data structures for implementing these abstract data types, such as balanced search trees, hashing, heaps, and disjoint forests. Design and comparison of data structures. Introduction to lower bounds.

cmCourseInfo.description: Standard algorithm design techniques: divide-and-conquer, greedy strategies, dynamic programming, linear programming, randomization, network flows, approximation algorithms. Brief introduction to NP-completeness: polynomial time reductions, examples of various NP-complete problems, self-reducibility. Additional topics may include approximation and randomized algorithms. cmCourseInfo.description: Effective communication is a pivotal skill when public speaking, persuasive discourse, and personal presence are key to success. In this introductory course, students will strengthen and develop confidence in a supportive, playful, highly participatory and collaborative environment. This course is suited to students in professional programs or for those who would like to learn a full range of communication skills. Exploration of language structure, argumentation, grounding, alignment, vocal resonance, clarity and effective listening will be part of each class with an emphasis on enhancing individual potential.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Communication

courses.name: Introduction to Diaspora and Transnational Studies I

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 12: Session changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: What is the relationship between place and belonging, between territory and memory? How have the experiences of migration and dislocation challenged the modern assumption that the nation-state should be the limit of identification? What effect has the emergence of new media of communication had upon the coherence of cultural and political boundaries? All of these questions and many more form part of the subject matter of Diaspora and Transnational Studies. This introductory course ex-amines the historical and contemporary movements of peoples and the complex issues of identity and experience to which these processes give rise as well as the creative possibilities that flow from movement and being moved. The area of study is comparative and interdisciplinary, drawing from the social sciences, history, the arts and humanities. Accordingly, this course provides the background to the subject area from diverse perspectives and introduces students to a range of key debates in the field, with particular attention to questions of history, globalization, cultural production and the creative imagination.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Diaspora and Transnational Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to help students build communication skills in the Korean language. Through an integration of listening, speaking, reading and writing, it aims to provide a solid foundation in beginning-level Korean. This course assumes that students do not have any prior knowledge of Korean. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must fill out the Screening Form prior to enrolment: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/enrolment-instructions/korean . Failure to submit the form will result in removal from course. Students must also attend an interview as scheduled by the professor/program coordinator within the first of class. For more information, please contact eas.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Students must have a computer with a microphone, speakers and a webcam in order to participate. Students will be expected to self-study the asynchronous lecture on Saturdays/Sundays and on Wednesdays. Synchronous attendance required at tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Through various forms of popular culture in the 20th century, this course explores the cultural contexts and social trajectories of China, Japan and Korea. Forms of popular culture studied include art, visual culture, consumer habits, foodways, advertising, music, and fashion.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a critical examination of 20th-century Chinese literature, with a focus on the important developments of literary writing over time, from the inception of New Literature in the 1910s, the development of realism and modernism in the 1930s, to the emergency of post-revolution and postmodernist writings in the 1990s. Emphasis is placed on generating a dialogue on interpretations of key works.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces major issues and events in contemporary Chinese history from the success of the Communist revolution in 1949 to China's postsocialist transitions in the 1980s and early 1990s. Topics include the development and victory of the Chinese Communist revolution, the rule and legacy of Mao Zedong (particularly the Hundred Flowers movement, the Great Leap Forward, and the Cultural Revolution), and economic reform and political repression in the era of Deng Xiaoping.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mao's China and Beyond

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students must participate synchronously at the scheduled times.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course discusses documentary film and DV culture in contemporary China as forms of cultural, communal, and political practices. We focus on films and videos that seek to address important global issues such as peace, environment, and climate change in cross-media approach and in personal tone. We ask: What new tendencies are there in the films and videos? Where can we trace them back to? What fresh possibilities do they bring forth to our aesthetic and public life?
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Culture in Contemporary China

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

LEC0201 & 0301: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic (economy-wide) perspective. Topics covered include international trade and finance, role of money and the banking system, monetary and fiscal policy. Note: graphical and quantitative analysis are used extensively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of markets and prices. Determination of prices through the interaction of the basic economic units, the household as consumer and as supplier of inputs and the business firm as producer and as employer of inputs. The pricing system as the mechanism by which social decisions and allocation of goods are made in a market economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of output, employment and the price level; techniques for achieving economic stability; central banking and Canadian financial institutions and markets; foreign exchange markets and the exchange rate. This course is not intended for students enrolled in the BCom program; please see ECO209Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Term tests and assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones. Some adjustments could be made in order to proctor the assessments.
  • There will also be online quizzes, generally between 2 to 3 hours per quiz, within three-day windows to complete.

Learn how to analyze data and how to correctly interpret and explain results. Use Excel to analyze a wide variety of data and replicate tables and figures in economics research papers.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course demonstrates how a rigorous application of microeconomic techniques can inform our responses to various environmental problems. Topics may include: air and water pollution and renewable resource management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Economics and Policies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones. Some adjustments could be made in order to proctor the assessments.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys important features of energy markets and related environmental challenges. One of the central objectives is to provide an understanding of the key economic tools needed to analyse these markets. A related objective is the development of a framework for understanding the public discourse on energy and the environment. Topics include: the hydrocarbon economy (oil, natural gas and coal), electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, renewable energy, conservation, carbon taxes and ‘cap-and-trade’.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and the Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are conducted synchronously. These are recorded and posted online. There will be no in-person sessions. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Focuses on the core ideas and concepts of game theory and on applications of them in economics and other social sciences. Topics may include: oligopoly, electoral competition, the theory of public goods, voting theory, the free rider problem, repeated interaction, bargaining, evolutionary equilibrium, matching and auctions.

Note: This course cannot be taken as a substitute in programs that require ECO326H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Game Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

cmCourseInfo.description: A development of the microeconomic foundations of macroeconomic theory to expand students' analytic skills by constructing and solving macroeconomic models. Topics may include: dynamic choice, neoclassical growth theory, uncertainty and rational expectations, business cycles, as well as fiscal and monetary policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Economic Theory - Macro

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 25, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Ample empirical and experimental evidence suggests significant departures from classical assumptions of economic behaviour. For example, humans are neither always perfectly rational nor always self interested. This course describes systematic ways in which behaviour deviates from neoclassical assumptions, generating new, and hopefully more realistic behavioural assumptions that have broad empirical, theoretical and policy implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural and Experimental Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be predominately asynchronous, with some minor synchronous elements. Lectures will be posted as online videos, and students will have the chance to engage with the course material and each other through online discussion boards, and will complete all work digitally. Students will have flexibility in the timing of their course work, but will need to keep up to date with the course material, and be actively participating in the course on a regular basis, much like with a traditional course. Additionally, some course elements (participation in experiments), will require students to be available during one of several scheduled times. Students will need reliable Internet access via a computer with a working microphone.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 25, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Spatial economic theory and urban public policy: firms and individuals in partial and general equilibrium, land development and land-use controls, urban transportation, efficiency and equity in spending and taxing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online asynchronous. Tutorials will be online synchronous and recorded for asynchronous viewing. There will be synchronous online class discussions once per week and regular online office hours. Exams will be online synchronous.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note

Delivery Instructions

The course has asynchronous and synchronous elements. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

See department website for course prerequisites.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered as per course schedule. In special circumstances, recordings of lectures will also be made available for students to view asynchronously. Since participation during lectures is an important element of the course, It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economics of financial assets and financial markets. Topics: inter-temporal choice, expected utility theory, security valuation, selected asset pricing models, market efficiency, and the term structure of interest rates - essential materials for an understanding of the role and operation of financial markets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Agency and incomplete information problems inherent in financial transactions; the role of contractual arrangements in overcoming them. Financial constraints on investment decisions of firms; the financial system in economic growth; the legal system in the functioning of financial markets. A look at theoretical and empirical literature covering these issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics II: Corporate Finance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage. The second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Trade Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to open economy macroeconomics and international finance. The core objective of the course is to develop macroeconomic models of open economies that can be applied towards gaining an understanding of recent events such as US deficits, financial crises, China's exchange rate policy and the Euro.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Monetary Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to econometrics similar to ECO375H1, with greater focus on applications drawn from business and financial economics. The course is built around the statistical foundations and economic applications of the multiple regression model. Using statistical software, students will also learn how to conduct, present, and critique empirical research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forecasting and Time Series Econometrics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to econometrics. Statistical foundations and the interpretation of multiple regression models, with an emphasis on cross-sectional data. Application of regressions to a wide variety of economic questions and data sources, including the use of statistical software. Problems in the identification of causality, and an introduction to methods of addressing common statistical issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course in applied microeconomics is concerned with the functioning of markets and the behaviour of firms within these markets. The focus is on strategic relationships between organizations, including competitive relationships among firms in the same market and cooperative relationships between a firm and its suppliers and distributors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Markets, Competition, and Strategy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides a general treatment of the economics of energy markets and the use of regulation in addressing environmental and other issues arising in these markets. A central theme is the search for an appropriate balance between market forces and regulatory/government intervention. Familiarity with tools of microeconomics and statistics/econometrics is essential. Topics include: oil, natural gas, coal and electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, networks, feed-in-tariffs, carbon taxes, ‘cap-and-trade’ and incentive regulation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and Regulation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are conducted synchronously. These are recorded and posted online. There will be no in-person sessions. Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the price, distribution, and growth theories of major economic thinkers before 1870, from pre-classical contributions by Aristotle, Mercantilists, and Physiocrats to the classical authors Adam Smith, David Ricardo, T.R. Malthus, and Karl Marx.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Economic Thought

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered as per course schedule. Recordings of lectures and tutorials will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities (ie. Quercus discussion groups). BbCollaborate will be used.

cmCourseInfo.description: Evolution and adaptation of life on Earth. Introduction to the theory of evolution by natural selection. Topics may include: evidence supporting the fact of evolution, and how evolutionary theory can help explain the world around us, such as how species are formed, and the evolution of sex, infanticide, and disease. For non-science students in all years and disciplines. For non-science students in all years and disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Evolution and Adaptation

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is an online synchronous course with occasional review lectures recorded for asynchronous viewing and attendance will be mandatory.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the scientific discipline that deals with threatened species and habitats. Topics include: biodiversity, extinction, threats, demography, genetic diversity, protecting, managing and restoring ecosystems (e.g., nature reserves, captive breeding, conservation corridors), sustainable development, and global warming. Ties between the study of conservation biology and environmental law, economics, and policy will also be covered. For non-science students in all years and disciplines. For non-science students in all years and disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Conservation Biology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is an online course including both synchronous and asynchronous content. Lecture content will be posted as a series of videos in 20 min to one hour units. Students will have the opportunity to attend 1-2 hour live lectures/webinars once per week which will be posted following the live event. There is a required hour of synchronous tutorial content each week and attendance is mandatory.

cmCourseInfo.description: Avian ecology, behaviour, conservation, and functional morphology and evolution of avian flight. Labs focus on avian anatomy and song analysis, and an outdoor activity introduces students to basic avian identification and compiling a field journal.
cmCourseInfo.title: Diversity of Birds

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Research Project in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate research project requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be one mutually agreed on by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. This course is open to highly self-motivated students who are in their Third Year and have a strong interest in ecology and/or evolutionary biology. Students are required to write up the results of their research in a formal paper, often in the format of a research article, and may be required to present the results at a poster session and/or participate in an oral presentation. Students should contact their potential supervisors over the summer before classes begin in September. Information regarding how to register for the course is available on the EEB website. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: cannot enrol if already taken the fourth year research project course EEB498Y1/EEB499Y1.

courses.name: Research Studies in Ecology & Evolutionary Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: An independent studies half-course allowing students to produce a literature review, which is supervised by a faculty member in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Highly motivated fourth-year students will work closely with a supervisor and be required to write up the results of their research in a final research paper. Students should contact a potential supervisor well before classes begin in the fall, winter, or summer session. Information on how to apply for the course is available on the EEB website. Students cannot take more than two independent research courses of EEB 497H1, 498Y1, and 499Y1, and the second project must be with a different supervisor. Students who apply to EEB497H1 in the fall session can also apply to enrol concurrently in EEB488H1Y. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

courses.name: Advanced Research Project in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced research project (a literature review alone is not sufficient) requiring the prior consent of a member of the Department to supervise the project. The topic is to be one mutually agreed on by the student and supervisor. They must arrange the time, place, and provision of any materials and submit to the Undergraduate Office a signed form of agreement outlining details prior to being enrolled. This course is normally open only to highly self-motivated students who are in their Fourth-Year and have adequate background in ecology and/or evolutionary biology. Students are required to write up the results of their research in a formal paper, often in the format of a research article, and are also required to present the results at a poster session and/or oral presentation. The time commitment is approximately 8 hours per week. Students should contact their potential supervisors over the summer before classes begin in September. Information regarding how to register for the course is available on the EEB website. Students in this course are also concurrently enrolled in EEB488H1Y Research Issues in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical tools for writing in university and beyond. Students will gain experience in generating ideas, clarifying insights, structuring arguments, composing paragraphs and sentences, critiquing and revising their writing, and communicating effectively to diverse audiences. This course may not be counted toward any English program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Effective Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical tools for writing in university and beyond. Students will gain experience in generating ideas, clarifying insights, structuring arguments, composing paragraphs and sentences, critiquing and revising their writing, and communicating effectively to diverse audiences. This course may not be counted toward any English program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Effective Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the stories that are all around us and that shape our world: traditional literary narratives such as ballads, romances, and novels, and also non-literary forms of narrative, such as journalism, movies, myths, jokes, legal judgments, travel writing, histories, songs, diaries, biographies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Narrative

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to British literature, exploring works in poetry, prose, and drama from the medieval period to the end of the seventeenth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to British Literature I

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to British literature, exploring works in poetry, prose, and drama from the end of the seventeenth century into the twentieth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to British Literature II

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the Canadian short story, this course emphasizes its rich variety of settings, subjects, and styles.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Canadian Short Story

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to book-length sequential art, this course includes fictional and nonfictional comics, with a focus on formal properties such as narrative layout and text/art hybridity. Themes vary but may include superheros; auto/biography; the figure of the outsider; women in comics; alienation and youth; and war reporting.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Graphic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores speculative fiction that invents or extrapolates an inner or outer cosmology from the physical, life, social, and human sciences. Typical subjects include AI, alternative histories, cyberpunk, evolution, future and dying worlds, genetics, space/time travel, strange species, theories of everything, utopias, and dystopias.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to American literature, exploring works in a variety of genres, including poetry, fiction, essays, and slave narratives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to American Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to Canadian literature, exploring works in poetry, prose, and drama from early to recent times.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Canadian Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the relations between digital technology and literary studies. Students will use such tools as computer-assisted analysis, digital editions, and visualization to ask new questions about literature. Readings may include born-digital fiction. Students will gain hands-on experience with digital technology, but no programming experience is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Digital Text

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of selected novels of Jane Austen and of works by such contemporaries as Radcliffe, Godwin, Wollstonecraft, Wordsworth, Edgeworth, Scott, and Shelley, in the context of the complex literary, social, and political relationships of that time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Austen and Her Contemporaries

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores six or more works by at least four British contemporary writers of fiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary British Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of plays in English by such dramatists as Wilde, Yeats, Shaw, Synge, Glaspell, Hughes, O'Neill, as well as plays in translation by such dramatists as Ibsen, Chekhov, Strindberg, Pirandello.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Drama

cmCourseInfo.description: Close encounters with recent writing in Canada: new voices, new forms, and new responses to old forms. Texts may include or focus on poetry, fiction, drama, non-fiction, or new media.
cmCourseInfo.title: New Writing in Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores twentieth-century American writing in a variety of genres.
cmCourseInfo.title: American Literature 1900 to the present

courses.name: Topics in Indigenous, Postcolonial, Transnational Literatures

cmCourseInfo.description: Sustained study in a topic pertaining to Indigenous, postcolonial, or transnational literatures. Content varies with instructors. See Department website for current offerings. Course may not be repeated under the same subtitle.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Indigenous, Postcolonial, Transnational Literatures

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores English from its prehistory to the present day, emphasizing Old, Middle, and Early Modern English and the theory and terminology needed to understand their lexical, grammatical, and phonological structure; language variation and change; codification and standardization; literary and non-literary usage.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of the English Language

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ENV100H1F will be conducted entirely online. Lectures and tutorials will be conducted asynchronously.
Each noon on the day of the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures. 
Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will consist of a mixture of online chat rooms, email inquiries, videoed how-to sessions.
Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments via Turnitin.

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ENV100H1S will be conducted entirely online. 

Lectures will be conducted asynchronously, and tutorials will be conducted synchronously. 

Each noon on the day of what was the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures. 

Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will be optional synchronous tutorial sessions through Blackboard Collaborate, which will be recorded and available for individual viewing, and will be offered to help students prepare for assignments. 

Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments, including a final assessment during the final assessment period, via Turnitin.

courses.name: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment

cmCourseInfo.description:
The perspective which scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity.

This living things and their environment breadth course is intended to fulfill the environmental literacy requirement for students in the BA programs of the School of the Environment or the living things and their environment breadth course requirement for Commerce, Humanities and Social Science students
cmCourseInfo.title: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

The lectures, tutorials, assignments and final exam are asynchronous. 
The only component that makes this course synchronous is the mid-term test. You will log on to Quercus during a specific time to take the mid-term test.

cmCourseInfo.description: One of two foundation courses for the School’s undergraduate program. Introduces students to ways in which different disciplines contribute to our understanding of environment. Instructors and guest lecturers are drawn from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities and will present subject matter, assumptions, conceptualizations and methodologies of their disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multidisciplinary Perspectives on Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course. 
Lectures will be delivered live during the regularly scheduled lecture hours (Mondays and Wednesdays, 2 – 4 pm, EST) via Blackboard Collaborate, and every attempt will be made to record them for later (re)viewing. Power point presentations will be uploaded in batches, but class discussions will not be recorded. 
There will be three writing assignments and up to five synchronous tutorials. Students will be expected to upload their papers in word format onto Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Geologic hazards: earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunamis. The distribution and politics of natural resources, including petroleum and ore deposits. Nuclear power and nuclear waste disposal. Global change: the geologic record of hot and cold climates, and how the earth survives. ESS103H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science, it will be taught in odd years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geology in Public Issues

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

There is a required textbook. Do not buy a used textbook. You can contact the instructor for financial assistance with the textbook when the course begins.

Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. There will be office hours hosted on Blackboard Collaborate to give everyone a chance to ask questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: The evolution of ideas about the origin and development of the earth from the Athenians to the 20th Century, with attention on the age of earth; on the evolution and disappearance of species; on the origin of oceans, continents and mountains; on climate change; and on the courage of scientists in confronting the religious and political views of their time. ESS104H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science students. Taught in even years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Controversies in Earth Science

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: The nature and evolution of the Earth; plate tectonics; rocks and minerals; volcanism; geological time; fossils; geology of Ontario; environmental issues; and human interactions with the planet. ESS105H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science students
cmCourseInfo.title: Our home planet

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. There will be office hours hosted on Blackboard Collaborate to give everyone a chance to ask questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: The emergence of society as a major geological force is considered in terms of the evolving debate about the consequences of human activity for the habitability of our planet. Major issues such as climate change, environmental pollution, and depletion of natural resources are examined.
cmCourseInfo.title: Confronting Global Change

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: A two-week field course in early May or late August. Students are introduced to field geology and to basic field measurement, mapping and documentation techniques (for example in the Espanola - Manitoulin Island area, west of Sudbury). Students are responsible for the cost of board and lodging and transport to and from the field area. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: Enrollment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A two-week advanced geological mapping project in a challenging field environment. Students learn to compile existing geoscience data, create a geological map and prepare a professional final report on their activities and findings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca.
