courses.name: Introduction to the Modern Middle East

cmCourseInfo.description: The emergence of modern states in the Middle East, against a background of empire, world wars, and national and religious movements. Students will learn why the modern map looks the way it does, and how Middle Eastern peoples' self-identifications have changed over the past 200 years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Modern Middle East

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: May 27, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the political, social, and religious history of modern Iran from pre-modern times to the 21st century. After a brief overview of political developments in the 18th century from the fall of the Safavids until the establishment of the Qajar dynasty, we will discuss the Constitutional movement of 1906 and the subsequent establishment of the Pahlavi dynasty, and focus on the Islamic Revolution of 1979 and the making of a modern theocratic state.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Iran
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NMC103H1 or permission of the instructor
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NMC451H1 may not be taken in the same year

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: A thematic treatment of the Arab lands of the Middle East and North Africa from 1700 onward, focusing on the Ottoman and colonial periods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Arab History

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students with no prior knowledge of Arabic. It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills: reading, writing, listening, and speaking. The learning philosophy underlying this approach is that proficiency in a foreign language is best achieved through consistent, deliberate, and systematic practice. From the outset, students are strongly encouraged to develop the habit of consistently practicing learned material.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Standard Arabic
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Peace and Conflict Studies Independent Study Course

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to explore topics not covered in the curriculum, or to develop a more detailed focus on topics covered. Approval of the program director is required. The student must obtain written agreement of the instructor who will supervise the independent study, submit the proposal to and obtain approval from the director and program administrator, who will then add the student to the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.


Applications are due two weeks before course enrollment deadlines for each semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Peace and Conflict Studies Independent Study Course
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: For students enrolled in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Major or Specialist program.

cmCourseInfo.description: A formal opportunity to gain hands-on experience and develop their skills within a research laboratory setting. Students will have a chance to become familiar and efficient at good lab practices, develop critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and developing trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

courses.name: Research Abroad in Pharmacology and Toxicology

cmCourseInfo.description: An independent research project in a pharmacology and/or toxicology laboratory in an approved partner university. This international research experience will be supervised by a faculty member at the partner institution and will allow students to develop critical thinking and evaluation skills while applying their knowledge and trouble shooting skills to practical research questions. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Abroad in Pharmacology and Toxicology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1 (65%), PSL300H1 (65%), PSL301H1 (65%); permission from the Undergraduate Coordinator

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Delivery Instructions

Health and safety guidelines and University travel policy will determine the status of this opportunity at the time of study.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course affords students an opportunity for hands-on research experience in a laboratory or applied pharmacology setting. Students will work under the supervision of a faculty member and will submit a final written report and oral presentation. Enrollment is limited and requires permission from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors can be obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). Students will be registered in the course once their ballot form (obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology) is signed by an approved supervisor and approved by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. Students are expected to spend approximately 200 hours towards this project but this will be project/supervisor dependent. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Project in Pharmacology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL366H1/PCL367H1/PCL368H1, STA288H1/PCL376H1, and permission of Department

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.content:

This is a remote, hybrid course. The course will run primarily as asynchronous (i.e., students will work directly with their supervisor on project requirements), with some synchronous online meeting components to be determined at the outset of the course with the course coordinator. 


Students enroll in this course through the Department. Please email undergrad.pharmtox@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

LEC0101/LEC9101 - learning for this course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. There are no formal lecture meetings as part of this course. 

If Public Health and institutional guidelines allow, and by mutual agreement of the student and faculty supervisor, in-person meetings may be arranged.

Students will work under the supervision of a staff member and will submit a final written report and oral presentation. It is the student’s responsibility to secure a placement with an approved supervisor before the course begins (a list of potential supervisors can be obtained from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology). Students will be registered in the course once their ballot form (obtained from the Department of Pharmacology) is signed by an approved supervisor and approved by the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology. Students are expected to spend approximately 200 hours towards this project but this will be project/supervisor dependent. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PCL201H1, PCL302H1, PCL366H1/PCL367H1/PCL368H1, STA288H1/PCL376H1, and permission of Department

The goal is to deepen the student’s understanding of the scientific basis and practical techniques relevant to modern pharmaceutical development. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the central branches of philosophy, such as logic, theory of knowledge, metaphysics, ethics, and political philosophy. Writings from the central figures in the history of Western and non-Western philosophy, as well as contemporary philosophers, may be considered.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Philosophy (Historical)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: PHL101Y1, PHL201H1, PHLA10H3, PHLA11H3, PHL101H5, PHL102H5, PHL105Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Central texts of the pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, and post-Aristotelian philosophy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be live-streamed via Zoom and recorded for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials will be live-streamed via Zoom. A web camera and microphone are needed for tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to some of the post-Hegelian thinkers who inspired the various philosophical movements broadly referred to as continental, such as phenomenology, existentialism, deconstruction, and post-modernism. Questions include the will, faith, death, existence, history and politics, rationality and its limits, encountering an other. Authors studied may include: Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Marx, Freud, Heidegger, Sartre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Continental Philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to issues in the fundamental branches of philosophy: metaphysics, which considers the overall framework of reality; epistemology, or the theory of knowledge; and related problems in the philosophy of science. Topics in metaphysics may include: mind and body, causality, space and time, God, freedom and determinism; topics in epistemology may include perception, evidence, belief, truth, skepticism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Knowledge and Reality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed as per the schedule via BB Collaborate. Recordings of the lecture will be posted on Quercus for asynchronous viewing. A microphone will be required for participation in tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Consciousness and its relation to the body; personal identity and survival; knowledge of other minds; psychological events and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Persons, Minds and Bodies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Pre-recorded lectures will be posted on Tuesdays for asynchronous viewing. The Thursday meeting section will be a discussion session that is livestreamed using BB Collaborate. A microphone and camera are required for participation.

cmCourseInfo.description: Philosophical issues about sex and sexual identity in the light of biological, psychological and ethical theories of sex and gender; the concept of gender; male and female sex roles; perverse sex; sexual liberation; love and sexuality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Philosophy of Human Sexuality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to formal deductive logic. Semantics, symbolization, and techniques of natural deduction in sentential logic. Symbolization, natural deduction, and models in monadic predicate logic. Symbolization and natural deduction with polyadic predicates. Introduction to advanced concepts in first-order logic, such as operations, identity, and models.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Symbolic Logic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Justifications for the legal enforcement of morality; particular ethical issues arising out of the intersection of law and morality, such as punishment, freedom of expression and censorship, autonomy and paternalism, constitutional protection of human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Law and Morality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of environmental issues raising questions of concern to moral and political philosophers, such as property rights, responsibility for future generations, and the interaction of human beings with the rest of nature. Typical issues: sustainable development, alternative energy, the preservation of wilderness areas, animal rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting times via Zoom. Lectures will be recorded for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to central issues in ethics or moral philosophy, such as the objectivity of values, the nature of moral judgements, rights and duties, the virtues, and consequentialism. Readings may be drawn from a variety of contemporary and historical sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed as per the meeting schedule via Zoom. Lecture recordings will be posted on Quercus for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials will be held as per the meeting schedule and will require a microphone and camera for participation.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the study of moral and legal problems in medical practice and in biomedical research; the development of health policy. Topics include: concepts of health and disease, patient rights, informed consent, allocation of scarce resources, euthanasia, abortion, genetic and reproductive technologies, human research, and mental health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.title: Plato

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL210Y1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

cmCourseInfo.description: German and French philosophy after World War II, focusing on such topics as: debates about humanism, hermeneutics, critical theory, the structuralist movement, its successors such as deconstruction. Typical authors: Heidegger, Gadamer, Habermas, Levi-Strauss, Foucault, Derrida.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL217H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Philosophy of Mind
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One of COG250Y1/PHL240H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level study of selected issues in moral philosophy, or of influential contemporary or historical works in ethical theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL275H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be livestreamed via Zoom as per the schedule and recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing. Students will require a microphone in order to participate in discussions.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level study of moral and legal problems, including the philosophical significance of death, the high-tech prolongation of life, definition and determination of death, suicide, active and passive euthanasia, the withholding of treatment, palliative care and the control of pain, living wills; recent judicial decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics: Death and Dying
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL281H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. The instructor will post a 2-hour pre-recorded lecture each week. 1-hour of the scheduled time will be used for a live-streamed lecture which will be recorded for asynchronous viewing. The remaining 2-hours will be used for an optional discussion session and office hours. A microphone and webcam is preferred for the fullest learning experience.

cmCourseInfo.description: The literary expression of philosophical ideas and the interplay between literature and philosophy. Such philosophical issues as the nature and origin of good and evil in human beings, the nature and extent of human freedom and responsibility, and the diverse forms of linguistic expression. Such authors as Wordsworth, Mill, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Miller, Camus, and Lawrence are studied.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Philosophy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting times via BB Collaborate. Lectures will also be recorded for asynchronous viewing. A camera and microphone is recommended for those who wish to participate during synchronous lectures.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of key philosophical works published within the last five years.
cmCourseInfo.title: New Books Seminar

cmCourseInfo.description: This course engages students in in-depth learning about HIV research. In addition to learning about methods and issues from a variety of research disciplines as applied to HIV, students will be expected, with guidance, to design a study relevant to the content of the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: HIV Prevention Research

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course provides a survey of Physics, including both Classical and Modern Physics. It is designed for non-scientists, and assumes no background in either science or mathematics. The approach to the course is broad rather than deep. We will concentrate on the concepts underlying such fascinating topics as planetary motion, chaos, the nature of light, time travel, black holes, matter waves, Schrodinger's cat, quarks, and climate change. We will uncover the wonders of the classical and the quantum worlds courtesy of Galileo, Newton, Maxwell, Einstein, Heisenberg and many others.

(PHY100H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Science)
cmCourseInfo.title: The Magic of Physics

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an on-line course. Recordings of the lectures only (no discussion) will be made available afterwards for those unable to attend during class time. Tutorials will follow the same principle. Some synchronous attendance may be required, in particular for assessments. Further details will be provided at a later date.

cmCourseInfo.description: A first university physics course primarily for students not intending to pursue a Specialist or Major program in Physical or Mathematical Sciences. Topics include: classical kinematics & dynamics, momentum, energy, force, friction, work, power, angular momentum, oscillations, waves, sound.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Physics I
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: MAT135H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1 recommended, but may be required prerequisite in 2nd year Physics courses

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

Further details will be provided at a later date.

cmCourseInfo.description: The second university physics course primarily for students not intending to pursue a Specialist or Major program in Physical or Mathematical Sciences. Topics include: electricity, magnetism, light, optics, special relativity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Physics II
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: MAT136H1/MAT137Y1/MAT157Y1 recommended, but may be required prerequisite in 2nd year Physics courses

cmCourseInfo.description:
An introduction to the physics of everyday life. This conceptual course looks at everyday objects to learn about the basis for our modern technological world. Topics may include anything from automobiles to weather.

PHY205H1 is primarily intended as a Breadth Requirement course for students in the Humanities and Social Sciences.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Physics of Everyday Life
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: PHY131H1/PHY132H1/PHY151H1/PHY152H1 or equivalent, taken previously or concurrently

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in Electromagnetism. Topics include: Point charges, Coulomb’s law, electrostatic field and potential, Gauss's Law, conductors, electrostatic energy, magnetostatics, Ampere's Law, Biot-Savart Law, the Lorentz Force Law, Faraday’s Law, Maxwell's equations in free space.
cmCourseInfo.title: Electricity and Magnetism

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: The quantum statistical basis of macroscopic systems; definition of entropy in terms of the number of accessible states of a many particle system leading to simple expressions for absolute temperature, the canonical distribution, and the laws of thermodynamics. Specific effects of quantum statistics at high densities and low temperatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Thermal Physics

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: The course analyzes the linear, nonlinear and chaotic behaviour of classical mechanical systems such as harmonic oscillators, rotating bodies, and central field systems. The course will develop the analytical and numerical tools to solve such systems and determine their basic properties. The course will include mathematical analysis, numerical exercises using Python, and participatory demonstrations of mechanical systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Mechanics

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Failures of classical physics; the Quantum revolution; Stern-Gerlach effect; harmonic oscillator; uncertainty principle; interference packets; scattering and tunneling in one-dimension.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantum Physics

cmCourseInfo.description: Why do individuals, groups, and societies make repeated, and often easily predictable mistakes? Why do they persist in courses of action that produce disastrous results? Why is it that in the political world good intentions are insufficient to ensure good results? This course employs the political science analytical toolkit to answer these questions and examines an array avoidable disasters, from the local to the international.
cmCourseInfo.title: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Catastrophic Policy Failures, and Epic Marches of Folly
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: POL486H1 (Topics in International Politics I: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Policy Failures and Marches of Folly), offered in Winter 2019 and Winter 2020; POL487H1 (Topics in International Politics II: What Went Wrong? A Post Mortem of Political Disasters, Catastrophic Policy Failures), offered in Winter 2018

courses.name: Political Theory: Visions of the Just/Good Society

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective presentation of critical encounters between philosophy and politics, dedicated to the quest for articulation and founding of the just/good society. Among the theorists examined are Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes and Locke.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Theory: Visions of the Just/Good Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures will be delivered online synchronous.
  • Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.
  • Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings when indicated.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an introduction to the history and politics of economic and political development, starting with the Industrial Revolution and then turning to a critical analysis of the politics of economic growth, international trade, debt, state intervention, protectionism, and neo-liberalism in the global periphery, including Africa, Asia, and Latin America.
cmCourseInfo.title: Politics of Development

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedules.
  • All the planned lectures are posted and available on Quercus.
  • Students are encouraged to read required readings before class.
  • Students are required to have a computer with a microphone.
  • Camera is recommended in order to participate in online tutorials and discussion but not mandatory.

cmCourseInfo.description: This introductory course examines some key themes and issues in global politics, including interstate war, human rights, international institutions, and the evolution of the global order.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to International Relations

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Students will be expected to do readings and listen to lectures before tutorial meetings.
  • Online class discussions will be held during the scheduled lecture meeting times to discuss topics in the lectures and to assist students with course material.
  • Tutorials will be held during the scheduled meeting times and delivered online synchronously.
  • Students require a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online tutorials and lectures.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the study of Canadian government. Topics include institutions of governance: the constitution, machinery of government, charter of rights and freedom, and the electoral system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Government

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures will be delivered online synchronously and recordings will be available for students to view asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous, at their scheduled times.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces the foundations of quantitative empirical research methods - increasingly popular and important part of political science research and public policy debates - to enable you to interpret and evaluate the results of the studies that employ these methods. Topics include scientific study of politics, empirical research designs, and regression analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures are live-streamed and recorded, permitting synchronous delivery and asynchronous attendance.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building up on POL222H1, students will continue to build theoretical foundations of quantitative empirical research, such as probability theory and statistical inference. They will also learn the basic use of statistical software and have become able to conduct a basic data analysis by themselves by the end of semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Students will receive zoom link beforehand to attend each scheduled class and tutorial.
  • Summary of the lecture slides and notes will be uploaded on Quercus after each lecture.
  • Students are expected to have internet access, webcam, headphone and/or speakers for this course.

cmCourseInfo.description: The continuing relevance of pre-colonial Africa; the nature and legacy of colonial rule; African nationalism and the consolidation of power in the newly-independent states; government, party and the people; the role of the military; national integration; dependency and neo-colonialism; socialism and development; democracy and human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Government and Politics in Africa

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores China’s efforts to construct a modern and effective political order in the face of powerful demographic and revolutionary challenges. The clash between competing ideologies, political and social movements and institutional alternatives in the context of rapid social and economic change are analyzed.
cmCourseInfo.title: State & Society in 20th Century China

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions
  • Lectures will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: Draws from the major theoretical traditions in public policy and policymaking of the advanced industrial world, and applies these theories in understanding the developing world context and the new challenges of global change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Public Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: The development of political thought from the Enlightenment and through the 19th century; implications for political thought in the 20th century. Democratic and anti-democratic tendencies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Political Thought

cmCourseInfo.description: The foreign policy of the United States: tradition and context of American decision-making, the process by which it is formulated, application to a number of specific regions and problems in the world.
cmCourseInfo.title: United States Foreign Policy

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: International law as an instrument of conflict resolution. Recognition, sovereign immunity, subjects of international law, jurisdiction.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Law

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to Canadian political development – an approach that shows how attention to history can illuminate and explain patterns of Canadian politics. The course introduces students to core theories and tools of a developmental approach, then applies this approach to key moments, contestations, and institutions in Canadian politics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Political Development
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: POL382H1 (Topics in Canadian Politics: Canadian Political Development), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: Emotions are central to political life but have often been marginalized in political theory. This course explores various ways in which emotions are relevant to political theory and examines a number of contemporary debates around the new possibilities in bringing a positive consideration of the emotions back into political theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Emotions in Political Theory

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: The course explores the rise, evolution, and performance of the dominant neoliberal approach to development and poverty reduction. It also assesses the feasibility and efficacy of alternative development strategies. Case studies are drawn from Latin America, Asia, and Africa.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Economy of Development

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of neurophysiology, endocrinology and reproductive physiology for students enroled in Life Science programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Physiology I
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: BIO130H1/BIO150Y1; CHM138H1/CHM151Y1; and 1 FCE from any of the following: MAT135H1, MAT136H1, MAT135Y1, MAT137Y1, MAT157Y1, PHY131H1, PHY132H, PHY151H1, PHY152H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online course. Lectures will be posted online (4-6 hours/week). Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2 hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content (the sessions will be recorded). Students need the ability to view PDF files and must have access to Quercus (which includes access to Blackboard Collaborate). The assessment will take place during scheduled class time. The final assessment date and time will be announced by the Faculty of Registrar’s office.

Delivery Instructions

The lecture videos will be posted to watch asynchronously but help session & test will run synchronously. This means students have to ensure they are available Tuesday and Thursday 5-7 p.m. (Toronto Time).

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to go outside of the traditional university classroom and actively participate in a marine mammal autopsy. Learn the diversity and adaptive nature of marine mammalian physiology/anatomy as it compares to human. The course is 2 weeks (in May), one week of hands-on tissue dissection, and one week of group discussions of the findings and draft report preparation. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Physiology: Marine Mammal Autopsy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO270H1, BIO271H1/PSL201Y1/PSL280H1/PSL300H1, PSL301H1 or permission of the course coordinator

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSL378H1, 'E' indicator: this is a two weeks intensive summer field course from May 17 - 28, 2021. Week one will be in-person and virtual dissection at the University of Toronto, week two will be done virtually.   
Additional information and application may be obtained in http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl378h1f. 
Space is limited and requires course director approval no later than April 1, 2021. Please note that there is a course fee in addition to the university registration.

Delivery Instructions

Week one will be in-person and virtual dissection at the University of Toronto, week two will be delivered online synchronously.   
Additional information and application may be obtained in http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl378h1f. 
Space is limited and requires course director approval no later than April 1, 2021. Please note that there is a course fee in addition to the university registration.

courses.name: Comparative Marine Mammal Physiology in the Field

cmCourseInfo.description: Hands-on monitoring of physiological measures with live dolphins, manatee and sea lions; field observations and applied learning to a physiology project. Two-weeks at the end of April early May: 1st week at marine research center in Mexico, 2nd week of wrap-up discussion and integration of data at U of T. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Marine Mammal Physiology in the Field

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For PSL379H0/1, 'E' indicator: Additional information is available at http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl379h.  Please note that spaces are limited and is allocated on a first come first served basis.

Delivery Instructions

The Department of Physiology will be offering a two weeks virtual ‘up close and personal videos’ with various species of dolphins & seals.  The first week is spend on BBcollaborate virtually visiting our marine mammals and the second week will be virtual daily class meetings to discuss individual projects, group discussion of the information learned and applied.

On-line Course Date: April 26 - May 7, 2021

cmCourseInfo.description: A brief introductory survey of psychology as both a biological and social science. Topics will include physiological, learning, perceptual, motivational, cognitive, developmental, personality, abnormal, and social psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online.  Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.  Opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., virtual office hours) will be made available, but will not be required.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals of statistical analysis of experimental and observational data including linear models, the analysis of variance, a priori contrasts, post-hoc tests, power analysis and effect size calculations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statistics II

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings from live synchronous lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. All delivery (apart from assignment and quiz/assessment instructions) will take place during lecture and/or tutorial.  There will be an oral assessment at the end of the course which will require students to have a microphone and camera to participate. During lecture/tutorial/office hours, a microphone will also be useful to engage in class activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The developmental approach to the study of behaviour with reference to sensorimotor skills, cognition, socialization, personality, and emotional behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Development

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Opportunities for online synchronous meetings and tutorials with professor and/or TAs will be made available at variable times throughout the semester.  For all such meetings, students will be able to either attend the online synchronous session or listen to a recording of the meeting asynchronously.  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary areas of research in social psychology: social perception, attitudes, inter-personal relations, and group processes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held on May 13th 11am-1pm;  May 27th 11am-1pm; and June 10th 11am-1pm.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory and research in personality structure and dynamics: the interaction of cultural and biological factors in the development and expression of individual differences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Personality and Its Transformations

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be an online, asynchronous course. Lecture videos will be recorded and uploaded to the course website each week. Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous office hours each week to ask questions and get feedback. There will also be opportunities for synchronous activities with your classmates. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical survey of concepts, theories, and the state of research in the area of psychopathology and therapeutic methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Abnormal Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. There will be opportunities for live discussion with the instructor and/or TA during weekly scheduled meetings that will be available through an online platform. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Quercus for submission of the assignments and tests. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Concepts, theories, and applications of classical and contemporary learning theories, including classical and operant conditioning. Current theories of the physiological and anatomical basis of learning and memory, including synaptic plasticity, the role of the hippocampus, amygdala, frontal cortex and other brain regions. Theories will be related to a practical understanding and applications such as drug addiction, phobias and other disorders.
cmCourseInfo.title: Learning and Plasticity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture recordings will be available online for students to view asynchronously. Opportunities for synchronous activities (e.g. virtual office hours) will be available but optional or an asynchronous option will also be made available. Students will be able complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research and theory on the neural and cognitive architecture of attention, memory, language, thinking and reasoning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Synchronous office hours and review sessions will be scheduled throughout the term. It is recommended that students have a computer, a microphone, and internet access in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological basis of perception across the different sensory modalities in humans and lower animals, with an emphasis on vision. Exploring visual perception such as shape and objects, scenes, colour, space, and motion as well as auditory perception of simple and complex sounds, and location. Further topics may include touch, including perception of temperature, pain and body posture, the chemical senses, and cross-modal influences of the senses on one another. In-class demonstrations may supplement the lectures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sensation and Perception
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling approximately 4-5 hours/week and optional synchronous meetings for 1-2 hours/week. The schedule of the synchronous meetings will be arranged during the first week of class, with the aim to accommodate as many students as possible. Students should watch the lecture videos before the synchronous meetings. The synchronous meetings will be recorded for asynchronous viewing. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a solid background into the biological basis of behaviour. Animal and human research topics include functional neuroanatomy, neural signalling, sensory and motor control, motivational systems, and hormones, and emotions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Physiological Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1/COG250Y1, OR registered in the Cognitive Science program

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: A lecture course providing in-depth examination of specific topics/themes relating to Psychology. Content in any given year depends on instructor. Priority is given to PSY Major program students during the first enrolment period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Psychology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSY100H1, PSY201H1 (or exclusion), and one further 200-level PSY half-course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online asynchronously, though live synchronous class discussions and/or office hours will be available each week at a specific time and day.  Participation in synchronous activities will be optional and asynchronous options will also be made available. All course assessments will be conducted online. Students will be able to complete the course entirely asynchronously without it adversely impacting their mark.

cmCourseInfo.description: Age changes in sensory and perceptual processes, motor skill, learning, memory, and personality. Theory, methodological problems, social, cultural, and environmental influences that shape behaviour and attitudes towards and among the elderly.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology of Aging

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as a series of short videos totaling approximately 4-5 hours/week. Students are expected to collaborate with a small group of students to discuss important questions related to real-life applications of course material. This collaboration can be done asynchronously or synchronously according to students' preferences. Students will have the option of attending a synchronous feedback conference about their written assignments with the instructor or TA. It is recommended that students have access to a computer with a microphone and camera to participate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intensive study of social attitude development, description, measurement, modification, and organization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology: Attitudes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online.  The midterm test will be written on July 20th from 11am-1pm.

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the hallmarks of human behaviour is its diversity. Some of the ways in which we differ are thought to be relatively idiosyncratic (e.g., specific aspects of personality), whereas others are fairly systematic. Cultural psychology is one area of research in human behaviour that examines systematic differences resulting from individuals’ cultural backgrounds. This course will introduce you to the consideration of cultural variation in the study of human thought and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be an online, asynchronous course. Lecture videos will be recorded and uploaded to the course website each week. Students will have the opportunity to attend synchronous office hours each week to ask questions and get feedback. There will also be opportunities for synchronous activities with your classmates. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals with psychological issues in the law, with particular reference to criminal law. It focuses mainly on research that has been done on pretrial publicity, eyewitness testimony, rules of evidence, and other factors that might affect jury decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology and the Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded lectures and linked live-streamed office hours/practical sessions during a set time each week. Students are expected to watch the lecture before the live online office hours. All live-streamed content will be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. All course assessments will be conducted online.  The midterm test will be written on July 20th from 4-6pm.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 3, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Illustrates major methodologies within social psychology, such as attitude measurement, observation of small groups, and experiments. Course capacity is limited to 15 students and priority is given to PSY Specialists and Research Specialists during the first enrolment period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology Laboratory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course content will be delivered through a combination of pre-recorded (asynchronous) and live (synchronous) lectures. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous content prior to class meetings. Synchronous meetings will be delivered online (and recorded for later viewing or review). Students must have access to a computer that runs Windows, MacOS, or Linux, as a smartphone or tablet will not be sufficient for the data analysis component of the course. All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth review of the role of emotion in human psychology, with an emphasis on the links between emotion and cognition. Topics include theories of emotion, emotion regulation, emotional expression, and emotional experience, the role of emotion in decision-making, and the relationships between emotion, motivation and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Emotion

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be accessible online for students to view asynchronously.  Opportunities for live review with instructors and classmates will take place during the period of 2-3pm Eastern on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and these will be recorded for asynchronous viewing.  A computer with a microphone and camera is recommended for students interested in participating in synchronous components of the course (not required). All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A review of the field of positive psychology, which is the study of happiness and fulfillment. Topics include personal growth, meaning, hedonic and eudaimonic approaches to well-being, gratitude, awe, flow states, mindfulness and meditation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Positive Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online asynchronous course, however, course content will also be delivered as live-streamed lectures on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 12 – 3 pm EST.  All live-streamed content will also be recorded to allow for asynchronous viewing. Other opportunities for synchronous activity with instructors and classmates (e.g., discussions, virtual office hours) will be made available. A computer with a microphone and camera is recommended for students interested in participating in synchronous components of the course (not required). All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines various theories of how personality functioning may become impaired and corresponding psychotherapeutic interventions. Emphasis on empirical assessment of personality dysfunction and therapy effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Psychopathology and Psychotherapy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Live virtual tutorial sessions (optional) will be offered at a few points throughout the semester.  Students will be able to participate in the discussion online (synchronously) or listen to a recording of the meeting (asynchronously).  All course assessments will be conducted online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Current theories and data on human memory: processes involved in encoding, storage, and retrieval.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Memory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. All course assessments will be conducted online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Feb 17, 2020: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: The functional relevance of neurotransmitters, with particular emphasis on their role in mediating behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurochemical Basis of Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures and assessments will be available online. Recordings of synchronous sections will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Daily, monthly, annual and other rhythms and methods of measuring them. Behavioural and physiological aspects of biological clocks. The importance of rhythms in experimental design, in research on brain function, in affective disorders, and the use animals make of rhythms in migration and other behaviours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biological Rhythms

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed to allow for synchronous (real time) online viewing. Lectures also will be recorded (possibly audio only) to allow for asynchronous viewing or review. All course assessments will be conducted online. Tests will be held during the regular class time according to the syllabus and will be followed by a lecture.

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course focuses on the social psychology of interpersonal relationships between individuals, especially romantic or close relationships and friendships. It surveys what social psychologists have learned about the development, maintenance, disruption or dissolution of personal relationships, as well as current social psychological theories of interpersonal relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Psychology of Interpersonal Relationships

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a capstone lecture course surveying research on how the mind arises from the brain. The first objective of the course is to understand how processes in human brains (ranging from the firing of a single neuron to the dynamics of billions) support cognitive abilities (such as recognizing a face, remembering a birthday from childhood, understanding the words in a spoken lecture, or planning a route home from class). The second objective of the course is to understand the methods of contemporary cognitive neuroscience research, to enable students to read primary literature and to understand ongoing debates.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cognitive Neuroscience

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture course discusses the role of brain and body in the expression and experience of emotion in humans considered through the experimental, physiological, theoretical, and clinical literatures.

cmCourseInfo.description: The role of film as a mediator of thought and experience concerning religious worldviews. The ways in which movies relate to humanity's quest to understand itself and its place in the universe are considered in this regard, along with the challenge which modernity presents to this task. Of central concern is the capacity of film to address religious issues through visual symbolic forms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Film

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Religious violence and nonviolence as they emerge in the tension between strict adherence to tradition and individual actions of charismatic figures. The place of violence and nonviolence in selected faith traditions.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a critical study of the historical, aesthetic, and cultural formation of the concept of pornography. The course explores the relationship between sexual representation and sex work; works through debates about artistic merit and censorship and how they relate to larger issues of power, capitalism, and technology; and theorizes the relationship between sex and commerce. Readings will include work from feminist, queer, people of colour, and trans theorists in the cutting-edge field of porn studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sexual Representations: Critical Approaches in Porn Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media in Culture and Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course.

cmCourseInfo.description: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.
cmCourseInfo.title: Book History and Print Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.
cmCourseInfo.title: Readers and Readerships

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course.

cmCourseInfo.description: A deeper examination of key cases in the development of media, such as the invention of movable type, the mechanization of the printing press, standardization of call number systems (Dewey, LC, etc.), the advent of radio, television and internet. Topics vary from year to year, according to the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Revolutions

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: Social media tools and platforms are deeply embedded in our contemporary lives. But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, how we understand ourselves, and how our networked society and culture functions? Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions with reference to their everyday experiences and current examples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Technology and Networks

courses.name: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Feb 16, 2021: Contact hours updated.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will challenge your views on a wide range of issues that affect us all. It will also excite your interest in a unique sociological way of understanding your world. We will analyze the globalization of culture, emerging patterns of class, race, and gender inequality in Canada and internationally, criminal and deviant behaviour, and so on. You will learn to understand these and other pressing social issues by analyzing the way the social world is organized. These topics are further taken up in the sequel to this course, SOC150: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC101Y1, SOC102H1, SOC103H1, SOCA01H3, SOCA02H3; SOC100H5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Quercus, UofT 0365 MS Teams or Skype for Business

Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone for office hours.

This course will be asynchronous. Lecture videos will be posted on Quercus by the morning of the day on Tuesday and Friday weekly. Tutorials to review key concepts will be recorded and posted by your Teaching Assistants by the end of the day on Tuesday and Friday.

courses.name: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries

cmCourseInfo.description: In the sequel to SOC100H1: Introduction to Sociology I: Sociological Perspectives, this course will explore in more depth the topic of social inequality and the contemporary debates that animate sociology. We may like to think of ourselves as perfectly free but powerful social forces open up some opportunities and close off others, constraining our freedom and helping to make us what we are. By examining the operation of these social forces, sociology can help us know ourselves. The course is also about skills-building, skills useful not only for success at U of T, but beyond the walls of the university.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sociology II: Sociological Inquiries
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC101Y, (SOC102H + SOC103H), SOC200H1, SOC200Y1, SOCB05H3, SOC221H5, SOC200Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate)

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the history, nature, and role of sociological theory, through an examination of the works of key classical theorists such as Karl Marx, Max Weber, Emile Durkheim, Georg Simmel, and others. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Sociological Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

BB Collaborate, PowerPoint, MP4 and Word

Delivery Instructions

Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone.

Lectures will be synchronous.

courses.name: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction in quantitative social science research from descriptive statistics to hypothesis testing using various strategies for the analysis of bivariate relationships. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods in Sociology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC200Y5, SOC222H5, ECO220Y1, ECO227Y1, GGR270H1, PSY201H1, STA220H1, STA248H1, POL222H1, POL232H1, POL242Y1, POL322H1, STA288H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

BB Collaborate (through Quercus) and SPSS (free download); MS Word

Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone; Lectures and tutorials are synchronous.

Textbook: Healey, Joseph F., Steven G. Prus, and Riva Lieflander. 2019. Statistics: A Tool for Social Research, 4th Canadian Ed. Nelson Education Ltd.

The textbook is available as an e-book or as hard copy, both available at https://www.nelsonbrain.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/en/micrositesca/UofT-SOC202. The ebook comes bundled with MindTap Instant Access, the online platform this class uses for homework assignments ($59.95). The other option, hard copy text package ($131.95), provides the print text and an access code for MindTap. If you choose to purchase a used textbook, you will need to also purchase MindTap Instant Access.

courses.name: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Sociology

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the methods and issues of qualitative research, the theories, methods for data collection and analysis, and the personal and ethical issues relating to qualitative research. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Qualitative Methods in Sociology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC101Y1, or a combination of SOC102H1+SOC103H1, SOC102H1+SOC150H1, SOC103H1+SOC150H1, or SOC100H1+SOC150H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Quercus, BB Collaborate, PowerPoint and Skype

Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate); camera & microphone; PowerPoint.

Lectures and tutorials will be synchronous.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an overview of the study of crime and deviance. We critically examine how scholars have gone about studying crime and deviance (the methods they use and the statistics they employ) as well as the major sociological explanations for crime and deviance. We also consider the empirical evidence as it relates to the validity of these explanations and some of the policy fallout from different theoretical approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Crime & Deviance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Quercus, BB Collaborate (within Quercus) and Zoom, PowerPoint, Word & mp3 files

Delivery Instructions

Quercus

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an introduction to the systematic study of the influence of individuals, groups, and society on individuals' thoughts, feelings, and behaviours from a sociological perspective. The course emphasizes interaction among individuals, between an individual and a group, or among groups, all situated within particular social contexts. One core emphasis involves the ways that individual-level processes contribute to explaining social inequality in social groups and organizations. Topics include identity processes, social cognitions, attitudes, emotions, status processes, power relations, legitimacy, and justice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociological Social Psychology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course asks students to think critically about the role of law in society, and to develop a sociological understanding of law and legal institutions. The course will include theoretical approaches to understanding the role of law and legal authority, and the constitutive ways in which law affects, shapes, and is negotiated in everyday life. In addition, attention will be paid to the legal profession, including empirical research on lawyers, legal careers, and their relationship to fields of practice, with an emphasis on the relationship between the structure of the legal profession and law as a democratic institution.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Law
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC293H1 (Topics: Sociology of Law), offered in Summer 2018, Winter 2019, Summer 2019; SOC396H1 (Topics: Sociology of Law), offered in Winter 2013

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (MS Teams/Zoom); camera & microphone.

Lectures & slides posted on Mondays & Wednesdays; readings on Quercus

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines (1) the social causes of illness and disease, (2) the experience of illness, and social processes that shape both of these issues, including medicalization. It focuses on population health, the relation between agency and structure, and macro-micro connections. Professional health care is discussed to the extent that it provides context for analyses of illness patterns and experiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociology of Health and Illness

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone; lectures will be asynchronous; discussions will be synchronous during scheduled class times as per timetable.

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective introduction to major contemporary thinkers and approaches whose ideas have achieved wide influence, as well as an on-going inquiry into the nature and role of sociological analysis. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of key methods of qualitative research, and an opportunity to design and conduct qualitative research that draws from key debates, methodologies, and methods in the field. Restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Qualitative Methods in Sociology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the fundamentals of the social network perspective, including a short introduction to social network theory and a survey of major findings in social network research. We will study how patterns of relations between social actors develop and how they affect outcomes such as health, status attainment, and inequality. Students will write a proposal to conduct research from a social network perspective.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Networks
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC355H1, SOC294H1 (Topics: Introduction to Social Networks) offered in Winter 2018 and Winter 2020

notes.name: Course Note

Lectures uploaded by 12 p.m., on Tuesdays and will be available for one week.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines a variety of widely discussed social problems, including poverty, crime, substance abuse, sexism, climate change and urban sprawl, using sociological theories to understand the causes of these problems. Will also examine the “social construction” of these social problems and factors that influence public attention and concern.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Problems

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (BB Collaborate for Office Hours); camera & microphone.

Lectures will be pre-recorded and posted as a mix of MP3 videos & PowerPoint slides with audio.

courses.name: Immigration and Race Relations in Canada

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: April 16, 2021: Waitlist added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the economic, social, cultural and political impacts of 20th century immigration in Canada, and emerging race and ethnic relations. Topics include immigration policy; population impact; community formation; labour markets; enclave economies; welfare use by immigrants; the criminal justice system; racial conflict; multiculturalism and race; and equity policies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Immigration and Race Relations in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Quercus (Zoom); camera & microphone.

Pre-recorded lectures will be released at least 24 hours in advance of the class, which will then be discussed during class time.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how society has gone about controlling specific types of deviants (e.g., gang members, sex and drug offenders) and acts of deviance (e.g., organized crime, the deviance of social control agents). In examining these individuals and acts, attention is also directed to why they are defined as deviant and sanctioned, and why some types of deviance are less likely to be detected and sanctioned than others. Finally, consideration is also given to a range of sanctions that have been used to control deviance and the empirical evidence on their effectiveness. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Control
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 & 1.0 FCE from SOC251H1/SOC252H1/SOC254H1
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
SOC212H1

Distribution Requirements: Society and its Institutions (3)

Breadth Requirements: Social Sciences

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the social processes that characterize stratification and social inequality across the globe, by looking at whether global inequality is growing, shrinking or stagnant and the impact of globalization on global inequality, with particular emphasis on examining disparities over time in education, income/wealth and health. This is a program-only course and is restricted to sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Inequality
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SOC201H1, SOC202H1, SOC204H1 & 1.0 FCE from SOC251H1/SOC252H1/SOC254H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent Research courses allow students to pursue a specific topic of interest. These courses are offered at the 300-level, as full or half courses. Students work independently with a professor in the Department who acts as research supervisor. There are no formal class meetings, lectures, or readings other than what is agreed to with the supervisor. Professors accept supervisory responsibility at their discretion. They are not required to serve as research supervisors. It is recommended that students approach a professor working in the same sub-discipline of sociology. Often students become interested in a topic through a SOC course and approach the instructor of that course for supervision; however, this is not required. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For further details, please visit our website at: http://sociology.utoronto.ca/st-george-campus/courses-3/independent-research-course/
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have completed 10.0 courses towards their degree, plus a SOC course at the 300+ level to be eligible for 300-level Independent Research.

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course, we examine institutions of higher education as unique social contexts within which student mental health unfolds. In doing so, we will address mediating and moderating factors, which characterize the unique and varied socio-emotional experiences of students attending post-secondary. As such, we will distinguish and clarify social approaches to studying mental health – focusing on mentorship, funding, social support, academic demands and healthcare resources – from mental illness as characterized in medical disciplines. Students will be expected to read thoroughly and apply insights from the course to authentic mental health concerns facing institutions of higher education today. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mental Health and Education
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SOC493H1 (Topics: Mental Health and Education), offered in Fall 2018 and Winter 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the social foundations of thinking and action, with a focus on how individuals think and act through shared cognitive schemas that are embedded in larger social structures. The course is organized around a wide-ranging array of classical and contemporary theories that help explain the various factors that shape culture and cognition. There is a research component to put this analytical understanding into practice. Restricted to 4th-year sociology majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Culture and Cognition

Introduction to methods of cultural analysis. (Offered in alternate years).

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in statistical concepts and methods, emphasizing exploratory data analysis for univariate and bivariate data, sampling and experimental designs, basic probability models, estimation and tests of hypothesis in one-sample and comparative two-sample studies. A statistical computing package is used but no prior computing experience is assumed. Note: STA220H1does not count as a distribution requirement course.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Grade 12 Mathematics and one University course in the physical, social, or life sciences

courses.name: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis I

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to probability using simulation and mathematical frameworks, with emphasis on the probability needed for more advanced study in statistical practice. Topics covered include probability spaces, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, probability mass, density, and distribution functions, expectation and variance, independence, conditional probability, the law of large numbers, the central limit theorem, sampling distributions. Computer simulation will be taught and used extensively for calculations and to guide the theoretical development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability, Statistics and Data Analysis I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: STA247H1, STA255H1, STA257H1, ECO227Y1, STAB52H3, STA256H5, ECO227Y5

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to statistical inference and practice. Statistical models and parameters, estimators of parameters and their statistical properties, methods of estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, likelihood function, the linear model. Use of statistical computation for data analysis and simulation.

cmCourseInfo.description: A mathematically rigorous introduction to probability, with applications chosen to introduce concepts of statistical inference. Probability and expectation, discrete and continuous random variables and vectors, distribution and density functions, the law of large numbers. The binomial, geometric, Poisson, and normal distributions. The Central Limit Theorem. (Note: STA257H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course).
cmCourseInfo.title: Probability and Statistics I

cmCourseInfo.description: A rigourous introduction to the theory of statistical inference and to statistical practice. Statistical models, parameters, and samples. Estimators for parameters, sampling distributions for estimators, and the properties of consistency, bias, and variance. The likelihood function and the maximum likelihood estimator. Hypothesis tests and confidence regions. Examples illustrating statistical theory and its limitations. Introduction to the use of a computer environment for statistical analysis. (Note: STA261H1 does not count as a distribution requirement course).

Sampling inference, estimates of population mean and variances, ratio estimation. Observational data; correlation vs. causation, missing data, sources of bias.
